subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quiki-pedia?
msgSnippet: Ah, a topic I m very interested in - transliteration. :) Anyone can download the database and set up their own wikipedia if they want. So you don t actually
messageBody:
Ah, a topic I'm very interested in - transliteration. :)

Anyone can download the database and set up their own "wikipedia" if
they want.
So you don't actually need the permission of the wikipedia guys to set
up Quikipedia.
Of course you won't have a dot wikipedia dot org domain name, but it's
totally feasible.

IMHO:

1) It should be typed and stored as junior quikscript.
Senior is just junior with font shaping, a rendering issue, since we're
in a wikipedia mood:
See also: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_text_layout

2) Easy, just use the _correct_ British pronunciation.
Just kidding (mostly) please don't flame me. :-)
You'd either have to go with one pronunciation or you'd need to have a
separate wikipedia for each.

3) Which issues?
If we're talking about sorting then I'd go for:
1-40 followed by Loch, Llan, Examine and Excite since that's the order
they're introduced to us in The Quikscript Alphabet.

steveb_667 wrote:
>
> I have an idea & I would like some feedback on it.
>
> In short, I was wondering about the feasibility of having a Wikipedia
> written entirely in Quikscript.
>
> I'm not sure if anyone has ever proposed a similar idea to Wikipedia
> in the past. For the most part, Wikipedia has occasionally delved into
> giving artificial languages their own wiki. I have yet to know of
> Wikipedia giving a wiki to a phonetic alphabet.
>
> It is in my view that a Quikipedia would be a great asset to the
> existing Quikscript community. It would encourage enrollment growth,
> increase the alphabet's visibility to a larger community of people &
> help existing members practice with their typing skills in a rewarding
> manner.
>
> Hurdles, naturally, need to be overcome for this Quikipedia to become
> reality. These concerns include, but may not be limited to, the following:
>
> 1). What form of Quikscript to use? Junior? Senior? A mix?
>
> 2). How are we to resolve legitimate phonetic differences with the
> same word from different countries?
>
> 3). What system should we set up to resolve emergent issues with the
> alphabet?
>
> At any rate, have fun with the idea.
>
>
